Covalently Attached Graphene-Ionic Liquids Hybrid Nanomaterials: Synthesis, Characterization and Tribological Application Rashi Gusain,a Harshal P. Mungse,a Niranjan Kumar,b T. R. Ravindran,b Ramanathaswamy Pandian,b Hiroyuki Sugimura,c Om P Khatria,*
Hybrid nanomaterials offer task-specific functional properties besides the individual properties of constituent materials / elements. Herein, graphene-ionic liquids (Gr-ILs) hybrid nanomaterials are synthesized to integrate the friction-reducing properties of both ionic liquids and graphene nanosheets. Importantly, the remarkable mechanical strength of graphene improves the anti-wear performance, whereas covalently grafted ionic liquids facilitate the dispersion of Gr-ILs in the polyethylene glycol (PEG 200) synthetic lube base oil. Graphene, prepared by controlled chemical approach, is used for the covalent grafting of imidazolium ring. Three variable Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials, having bis(salicylato)borate (BScB), oleate (OL), and hexafluorophosphate (PF6) anions, are synthesized to control their surface properties. Detailed chemical and microstructural features of Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials are studied by FTIR, XPS, Raman, XRD, FESEM, and HRTEM analyses. The Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials as lubricant additives for PEG 200, significantly reduced the friction and the wear. Further, Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials offers remarkably improved anti-wear properties (55-78 %) compared to that of corresponding ionic liquids (7-39%) blends in the PEG 200 and it was attributed to the high mechanical strength graphene, which protects the contact interfaces against the material loss. The elemental and micro-Raman results of worn surfaces suggested the formation of tribo-chemical thin film composed of Gr-ILs and its tribo-chemical products with steel interfaces. The BScB anion constituted Gr-BScB showed maximum reduction in the friction, whereas OL analogue exhibited smallest wear. This study reveals the potential of task-specific Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials as novel additives for diversified tribological applications.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Graphene, an atomic thick planner sheet of carbon atoms arranged in hexagonal lattice structure, has emerged as a most promising material since its invention in 2004.1 Graphene exhibits high electric and thermal conductivity, excellent mechanical strength and large specific surface area, which promise its potential for widespread applications including supercapacitors, field-effect transistors, photocatalysis, water remediation, sensors, biomedical, lubrication and so on.2-4 Over the last one decade, several approaches have been established to prepare single / multilayer graphene and chemically converted graphene.5 The chemical reduction of graphene oxide (GO) is the most convenient and economic
approach for mass-scale production of graphene-based materials. However, the non-dispersibility of reduced GO (rGO) and graphene in both polar and non-polar solvents has been a major challenge for their utilization to several applications.
Recently, ionic liquids have been proven as suitable media for preparation and stabilization of various nanomaterials.6 Ionic liquids exhibit several advantages over the conventional solvents and surfactants; such as high thermal and chemical stability, excellent conductivity and inherent polarity.7 These remarkable properties of ionic liquids offer wonderful capability to make a thin film around the nanomaterials and facilitates their dispersion in various solvents and matrices. Han et al. have demonstrated that the dispersibility of carbon nanotubes in the water can be attained by strong absorption of amino-terminated ionic liquids on the carbon nanotubes.8 Polymerized imidazolium ionic liquids were found to interact with graphene nanosheets through non-covalent π-π interactions and provides their dispersibility in other ionic liquids.9 The functionalization of graphene/rGO with ionic liquids has been a topic of great interest to develop functional hybrid nanomaterials exhibiting novel properties. Graphene, a lamellar structured material, easily shears at the contact interfaces and reduces the friction. Moreover, high mechanical strength of graphene provides excellent anti-wear property and load-bearing capacity, which is usual drawback of ionic liquids. However, the dispersion of graphene in lube media has been a great challenge. In this context, Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials could be attractive alternative to the conventional nanomaterials for friction and wear reduction. Furthermore, the dispersibility of Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials can be controlled by tailoring the anionic structure of chemically grafted ionic liquids on the graphene nanosheets. In such novel hybrid nanomaterials, ionic liquids can play important roles to facilitate their dispersion in the liquid lubricants, prepare tribo-chemical thin film under the contactstress and reduce the friction; whereas graphene skeleton can reduce the friction and provide excellent antiwear property.
Bermudez et al. demonstrated that carbon nanotubes-ionic liquid lubricant significantly reduces wear rate and friction with respect to neat ionic liquid.14 The Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials prepared via ultrasound-assisted non-covalent interaction between graphene and ionic liquids, revealed enhanced tribological properties.15-17 The thin film of ionic liquid and graphene nano-fluids prepared by spinning on DLC coating exhibits remarkable reduction in friction and wear compared to that of neat ionic liquids in the vacuum. The enhanced tribo-characteristics were attributed to the formation of tribo film of graphene, which separates the contact surfaces.16 The graphene cross-linked by ionic liquids via electrostatic interaction greatly enhances the frictionreducing and antiwear abilities for the contact of steel/steel and was attributed to the synergies of ionic liquids and multilayer graphene to form the tribo-chemical thin film under the harsh friction conditions.18 In most of these studies, Gr-ILs hybrid materials were prepared by ultrasound-assisted blending, electrochemical exfoliation of graphite in the ionic liquids and mechanically-stirring using agate mortar, where the non-covalent interaction between the cation of ionic liquids and π-electrons of graphene skeleton is key driving force to afford the Gr-ILs hybrid nano-fluids in the ionic liquids.16-19 The physico-chemical properties of ionic liquids are tailored by constituted cations and anions. Hence, the lubricity and wettability of Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials can be tuned by exchanging the anionic moieties.20 Herein, three different GrILs hybrid nanomaterials are prepared by covalent grafting of imidazolium ionic liquids on the graphene nanosheets. The lubrication potential of prepared Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials is evaluated by measuring the friction and wear properties of their dispersion in the polyethylene glycol (PEG 200) synthetic
lube base oil. The Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials could be excellent alternative to the conventional additives, where the poor dispersibility, low mechanical strength conductivity are critical challenges. It is anticipated that a stable dispersion of task-specific Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials may find potential applications for new generation lubricant development.

Synthesis of Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials
GO, a precursor to chemically converted graphene, was prepared by harsh oxidation and then exfoliation of graphite powder using a mixture of NaNO3, H2SO4 and KMnO4 as strong oxidizing reagents. The oxidized product was washed with 30% H2O2 and 5% HCl solution in subsequent order to remove the undigested content of oxidizing reagents. The resulting dark brown product was washed several times with distilled water until acidic content was removed. This was followed by ultrasound-assisted exfoliation of oxidized product into water using ultrasonic probe. The prepared aqueous dispersion of GO was centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 20 minutes. The supernatant phase, which contains fine sheets of GO was separated and then used for chemical reduction. The reduction of GO was carried out by refluxing the aqueous dispersion of GO with hydrazine hydrate (Scheme 1a-b). During the reduction process, thoroughly dispersed dark brown GO eventually turned into the black color segregated rGO. The rGO was then thoroughly washed with distilled water to remove the excess and trapped hydrazine hydrate traces. The lack of functional sites and cohesive interaction between their nanosheets make rGO as chemically inactive material and shows immiscibility with most of solvents. In order to generate active functional sites, particularly, carboxylic groups on the defect and edge sites, the rGO was oxidized under mild condition using nitric acid as an oxidizing reagent (Scheme 1bc).21 The resulting product, enriched with carboxylic groups and residual oxygen functionalities was then used for grafting of bifunctional organosilane linker. In the subsequent step, the dispersion of carboxylic acid groups enriched graphene nanosheets was purged with nitrogen, prior to addition of CPTMS. The reaction mixture was then refluxed for 24 hours. The methoxy groups of CPTMS are prone to interact with carboxylic and residual oxygen functionalities of rGO, and provide the chloro-terminated graphene nanosheets (Scheme 1c-d).22 In the next step, Gr-IL hybrid nanomaterial was prepared by refluxing the toluene dispersion of CPTMS-functionalized graphene with 1- methylimidazole under the nitrogen for 24 hours. This reaction leads to covalent linkage of imidazole ring to the graphene skeleton as imidazolium cation and eliminated chloro group of CPTMS remains as chloride anion in the graphene-imidazolium chloride hybrid nanomaterial (Scheme 1d-e). The chloride anion was then replaced by bis(salicylato)borate (BScB), oleate (OL) and hexafluorophosphate (PF6) anions following the metathesis reactions with Li-BScB, Na-OL and K-PF6 salts, respectively (Scheme 1e-h). Each product was washed thoroughly with distil water (three times) to remove nonreactant content of salts and then rinsed with ethanol, prior to dry the product in the air-oven. The synthesized Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials having BScB, OL and PF6 anions are coined as Gr-BScB, Gr-OL and Gr-PF6 throughout the manuscript. The anionic precursor, Li-BScB salt was synthesized by the reaction of lithium carbonate, boric acid and salicylic acid (1:2:4 molar ratio) in distil water at 60° C.23
Characterization of Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials
The chemical grafting of imidazolium ionic liquids on graphene nanosheets was examined by Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) and X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) measurements. FTIR spectra of all samples (KBr pellets) were recorded using a Thermo-Nicolet 8700 research spectrometer with a spectral resolution of 4 cm-1. XPS spectra of all samples were collected on ESCA 3400 (Kratos Analytical Ltd.) photoelectron spectrometer using MgKα line as an X-ray source. The peak fitting of all XPS spectra was carried out through GaussianLorentzian function after performing a Shirley background correction. The adventitious carbon in the XPS analysis was found at 284.6 eV. Diffraction patterns of all samples were collected using Bruker D8 advance diffractometer operated at 40 kV and 40 mA with Cu Kα radiation of 0.15418 nm wavelength. Thermal decomposition characteristics of Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials were measured using Perkin Elmer thermo gravimetric analyzer under the nitrogen flow. The micro-structural features and elemental distribution of all samples were probed by Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FESEM) coupled with Energy Dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy, using Quanta-200F (FEI) electron microscope. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was carried out to probe the nano-structural features of Gr-ILs samples.

sections.heading: Tribo-evaluation of Gr-ILs Hybrid Nanomaterials
sections.text:
The polyethylene glycol (molecular weight: ~200, PEG 200) was used as a synthetic lube base oil for tribo-evaluation of Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials. Each Gr-IL hybrid nanomaterial was thoroughly dispersed in the PEG 200 by sonication. The viscosities at different temperatures and viscosity index of PEG 200 remains the same after blending of each Gr-ILs additive (0.02 mg.mL-1) as shown in the table S3. The tribo-evaluation of these dispersions was carried out by measuring friction and wear parameters using ball-on-disc standard tribometer (CSM Instrument, Switzerland) operating in a linear reciprocating mode. A 100Cr6 steel ball (φ = 6 mm, rms roughness: 26 ± 3 nm) was used as a sliding material against the stationary lubricated steel disc (316LN, rms roughness: 80 ± 12 nm). The elemental composition and mechanical properties of both steel ball and disc are provided in Table S1 and S2 (ESI). The steel ball and disc were ultrasonically cleaned by acetone and ethanol in subsequent order before they used for the triboexperiments. The sliding ball was mounted in a holder, which was connected through stiff lever coupled with friction force transducer. The friction coefficient was determined by linear variable differential transformer (LVDT) sensor measuring the deflection in the elastic arm. The tribo-experiments were carried out at variable normal loads (250 mN - 7 N) and variable sliding speed (1 - 9 cm.s-1). The stroke length and sliding distance of each test were marinated as 3 mm and 100 meters, respectively. All experiments were carried out at constant normal load of 2 N, linear sliding speed of 3 cm.s-1, stroke length of 3 mm, and sliding distance of 100 meters. Two-dimensional wear profiles of worn tracks were measured by using a Dektak 6M– stylus profiler fixing 5 mg contact load at scanning speed of 10 µm/s. A sharp diamond stylus tip with 12.5 µm radius of curvature was scanned across the wear track to generate 2D wear profile. The stylus is mechanically coupled to the core of an LVDT sensor. The morphological and elemental features on the worn areas were examined by using FESEM coupled with EDX. The microstructure analysis at sub-surfaces across the wear tracks were carried out by FIB-SEM (Model Auriga, Carl Zeiss with 30 kV Ga and electron sources) dual-beam system. Trenches of about 10 x 5 square micron areas were made by FIB (fine) milling with 200 pA probe current. One of the sides of the trenches lies across the wear track was then further fine-polished by 5 pA probe current. Smaller probe currents were used to minimize the Ga beam induced damages of the microstructure. Additionally, the angle between the beam and surface of analysis was kept almost zero in order to minimize the beam damage. The fine-polished surfaces were then scanned by electron beam with 1-3 keV energy for imaging in secondary electron mode. The wear scar width and depth values are the mean of five different measurements of each sample. Micro-Raman spectroscopic measurements were carried out to detect the chemical changes on the wear tracks. Raman spectra were recorded in the back scattering geometry using a Renishaw micro-Raman spectrometer (Model INVIA) equipped with an Ar-ion laser (λ = 514.5 nm).

Tribological properties of Gr-ILs as lubricant additive
Owing to high cohesive interaction, graphene nanosheets tend to agglomerate and show immiscibility with most of solvents and lube oils. The surface property of graphene nanosheets can be controlled by chemical grafting and that facilitates their dispersion in various medium and matrix. Herein, imidazolium ionic liquid was chemically grafted on graphene nanosheets and affinity of prepared Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials with PEG 200 lube base oil was controlled by changing the constituted anions (BScB, OL, PF6). All samples (Gr-BScB, Gr-OL, and Gr-PF6) exhibited good dispersibility in the PEG 200. The inherent polarity of ionic liquids enhances dispersibility of Gr-ILs in the PEG 200, driven by interactions between the ionic liquids and polar oxygen functionalities of PEG 200. This is further supported by excellent miscibility of imidazolium-BScB ionic liquids in the PEG 200.33

The cross-sectional microstructures of worn track of steel disc lubricated with PEG 200 and Gr-BScB exhibiting grains across the cross section are explicitly revealed in the Figure 15. The magnified image (Figure 15ai and bi) shows distribution of finer grains near the surface. Arrow marks clearly revealed cracks that possibly related to shearing of the grains under the dynamic contact pressure. This is an indication of subsurface fatigue leading to formation of voids that further generates severs wear. This behaviour is dominating in Figure 15a where neat PEG is used for lubrication of steel-steel contact. In addition, the elongated grains along the sliding direction suggest that the deformation has led to the formation of a banded structure moving along the sliding direction. Such a band structure usually forms during severe plastic deformation to accommodate the misorientation angle between consecutive grains.37 It is worth mentioning that when the contact pressure reaches the elastic limit the original interparticle distance is significantly reduced due to gross plastic flow of the matrix phase. The consequent enhancement of the strain gradient in the matrix is accommodated by dislocation density. The cross-sectional FESEM analysis further confirmed that subsurface deformation are significantly reduced (Figure 15b) while Gr-BScB is applied under the sliding contact.
Furthermore, micro-Raman spectroscopic analyses were made on the worn tacks of steel discs lubricated with Gr-ILs (Figure 16). First order peaks clearly shows D and G bands at ~1332 and ~1605cm-1, respectively, that is indication of carbonaceous tribo-film on the wear track. Under the tribocontact stress, plastic deformation of steel-steel sliding interfaces is activated resulting adsorption of graphene/graphitized substances. Red and blue shift of D and G bands, respectively, inside the wear tracks as compared to virgin samples signifies chemical interactions between the graphene/graphitized carbon and tribo-interfaces. Peaks at ~1114 and ~1447 cm-1 are attributed to the presence of transCHx.
38 Second order peaks of graphene/graphene oxide is not visible due to the presence of intense peaks at 2850 and 2943 cm-1 which correspondence to asymmetrical and symmetrical stretching mode of methylene chains present in the alkyl group of imidazolium ring and CPTMS of Gr-ILs, and PEG.39 Furthermore, peaks at 512 and 711 cm-1 were designated as Fe2O3
40 that is tribo-chemical product of steel sliding contacts in Gr-BScB wear track.
Fig. 16 Raman spectra obtained from the wear tracks of (a) Gr-BScB, (b) Gr-OL, and (c) Gr-PF6 hybrid lubricated system.
The chemical analysis of worn tracks by elemental mapping and Raman spectroscopy revealed the formation of tribochemical thin film composed of Gr-ILs, their decomposed products, and new products developed by tribo-induced interaction with steel surface. The shear-induced delaminated graphene nanosheets from Gr-ILs could interact with steel contact surface, as revealed by Raman results (Figure 16), and protect the tribo-interfaces against the material losses. Besides that low shear strength of tribo-chemical thin film provided by low symmetry and size differences of cation and anions in GrILs and weak van der Waals interaction between the graphene lamellae of Gr-ILs, reduced the friction significantly. This study demonstrates that Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials can efficiently reduced the friction and protects the sliding interfaces by integrating lubricity effect of graphene and ionic liquids.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
The present work demonstrates the potential of covalently interacted Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials for lubrication applications. The Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials were prepared by chemical grafting of imidazolium ring on the graphene nanosheets using organosilane as a bifunctional chemical linker. Three variable anions BScB, OL and PF6 were selected in Gr-ILs to probe their effect on lubrication properties. The synthesis of Gr-ILs and then exchange of different anions were confirmed by FTIR and XPS. Structural features of Gr-ILs hybrid nanomaterials were probed by XRD, FESEM, HRTEM and Raman analyses. The presence of ionic liquids thin film in GrILs facilitated their dispersion in the PEG 200.
